question: What's different about transfer credits from Advanced Standing?
answer:
With advanced standing,

  • You must have a master's degree in Computer Science, Software Information Systems, or Computer Engineering.
  • Advanced standing applies only to the Computer Science or Software Information Systems Track only.
  • You cannot transfer any credits
  • However, you only have 42 credits left to go on your degree.  Which is 30 credits less than the normal 72 credits
  • Other than declaring the advanced standing during the application process, no other actions are needed.
  • You must complete your qualifying exam after your first year in the program.

With transfer credits,

  • You can transfer up to 30 credits hours
  • You must file paperwork → see I want to transfer coursework from my MS into my PhD program, what do I do?

question: I'm interested in applying to CIS PhD program.  What should I do next?
answer:
Admission is competitive. Preference is given to applicants with strong credentials and appropriate undergraduate and/or professional preparation. Specific admission requirements for the program include:

  • Contact faculty in Computer Science and Software Information Systems to see if there will be opportunities in their respective labs. For PhD admissions, faculty have to be willing to be a mentor to you and/or provide funding for you (for full-time students without government funding or a fellowship).
  • A baccalaureate degree from a recognized institution. Students must show evidence of preparation in their chosen field sufficient to ensure profitable graduate study.
  • A satisfactory past academic performance as usually reflected by a grade point average of (or equivalent to) at least 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale) on courses related to the chosen field of Ph.D. study.
  • .  *****GRE is waived for Spring 2022 and Fall 2022 applicants********
  • Applicants whose native language is not English must score:
    • At least 83 on the Internet-based version of Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL),
    • A minimum score of 6.5 on the International English Language Testing System(IELTS) or
    • A minimum score of 115 on the Duolingo English Test
  •   Additionally, applicants will be required to take an English Proficiency Examination prior to the beginning of the first semester of study. Students who do not pass this examination must pass ENGL 1100 (English as a Foreign Language) with a grade of B or higher.
  • A personal statement that addresses the following:
    • Discuss why you are interested in obtaining a Ph.D., (b) your reason for seeking admission to UNCC's Computing and Information Systems program and the areas of research and/or faculty's research that are of interest to you, (c) what knowledge you are hoping to acquire in the program that you do not know now.
    • What academic and/or professional experiences have prepared you to pursue your Ph.D.?
    • Optional----Describe any extenuating circumstances that may have affected your past academic performance and/or anything else you think is important for the graduate admission committee to know when reviewing your application.
  • Three letters of reference from faculty and/or professionals working in the applicant’s field of interest that address the applicant’s previous experience and potential to do research.
  • Applicants can also include evidence of scholarly and creative activity (e.g. publication list, awards, results in national or international contests related to computing and information systems).


For more information please review the Graduate Admissions website: https://gradadmissions.uncc.edu/admissions-info/doctoral/

question: How do I declare a dual Concentration?
answer:
Dual concentrations are optional in the new MS Program and not available in the old MS Program.


Dual concentration can be completed in 30 credit hours.   Note, however, if your Capstone Requirement course overlaps one of your dual concentration's courses, you will need to take 1 elective in order to reach the total 30 hour requirement.

To declare a dual concentration you must submit two separate gpetitions.   One for each concentration (see How do I declare a standard Concentration?).   In the comment sections for both of these petitions, explicitly state that you are requesting dual concentrations and state in the given gpetition that it is a request for either your first or second concentration.

question: How do I declare a custom Concentration?
answer:
Custom concentrations are only apply to the old MS Program.   

They are not available in the new MS Program except in 1 rare circumstance. Generally, just follow the procedure "How do I declare a standard Concentration?" 

  • The rare circumstance is only if (1) you are in the new MS Program and (2) you are doing a MS Thesis and (3) you want the thesis to be part of your concentration – in that rare case see "Declare a Custom Concentration Using Masters Thesis" below.


A custom concentration can be of 3 different sub-types.   Depending on the sub-type you should follow one of the 3 sets of instructions below.   The 3 sub-types

are:

  • petition to accept a regular course that is not listed in the Concentration's official class list
  • petition to accept an Individual Study course as part of the Concentration
  • petition to accept an MS Thesis as part of the Concentration

Case I:   Declare a Custom Concentration Using Unlisted Regular Courses

First you must declare your Concentration following the instructions at "How do I declare a standard Concentration?"

Then you must submit one or more "Course Substitution" petitions at https://academicpetition.uncc.edu/.    For each course that is not on the Concentration's official list you need to submit a separate "Course Substitution" petition.

Note that if you are requesting 3 non-listed courses (i.e. requiring 3 "Course Substitution" petitions), you need to email filled out this form  MS_Customize_Concentration_Form instead.   Such requests require additional justification.

To submit the "Course Substitution" petition, sign in to the above gpetition webpage.   You will be asked a number of questions.   Your answers should be as follows:

  1. For Type select:    Course Substitution

  2. For Terms Affected by Petition enter:   <current semester and current year>

  3. For Select the Course : select the course you want to count toward your concentration. 

    Note: You must have already completed the selected course or at least be currently registered for it.

  4. For Petition Description enter:   I want to count this course towards my Concentration in <type you concentration name>

  5. For Exception to Policy enter:   

    I have already declared by my concentration as     <type in concentration name>.
    For the following reason, I am requesting that the requested course be accepted towards this concentration:

    <give your justification>

Note: Graduate petitions typically take up to 1 week to process.

Case II:  Declare a Custom Concentration Using Individual Study 6880

First you must declare your Concentration following the instructions at "How do I declare a standard Concentration?"

Then you must submit a "Course Substitution" petitions at https://academicpetition.uncc.edu/

To submit the "Course Substitution" petition, sign in to the above gpetition webpage.   You will be asked a number of questions.   Your answers should be as follows:

  1. For Type select:    Course Substitution

  2. For Terms Affected by Petition enter:   <current semester and current year>

  3. For Select the Course : select the ITCS 6880 course

    Note: You must have already completed the selected course or at least be currently registered for it.

  4. For Petition Description enter:   I want to count this course towards my Concentration in <type you concentration name>

  5. For Exception to Policy enter:   

    I have already declared by my concentration as     <type in concentration name>.
    For the following reason, I am requesting that the 6880 course be accepted towards this concentration because its topic fits this concentration:

         Project subject was:   <write the full title of the Individual Study Project>
             Advisor was:  <write the full name and email address of the faculty who supervised your individual study>

Note: Graduate petitions typically take up to 1 week to process.

Case III:   Declare a Custom Concentration Using Masters Thesis

First you must declare your Concentration following the instructions at "How do I declare a standard Concentration?"

Then you must submit one (or more) "Course Substitution" petitions at https://academicpetition.uncc.edu/.    For each 6991 course that you want to count to your Concentration you must submit a separate "Course Substitution" request.

To submit the "Course Substitution" petition, sign in to the above gpetition webpage.   You will be asked a number of questions.   Your answers should be as follows:

  1. For Type select:    Course Substitution

  2. For Terms Affected by Petition enter:   <current semester and current year>

  3. For Select the Course : select the ITCS 6991 course

    Note: You must have already completed the selected course or at least be currently registered for it.  Also, if you want to count multiple ITCS 6991 sections, you will have to submit multiple "Course Substitution" petitions.

  4. For Petition Description enter:   I want to count this course towards my Concentration in <type you concentration name>

  5. For Exception to Policy enter:   

    I have already declared by my concentration as     <type in concentration name>.
    For the following reason, I am requesting that the master thesis be accepted towards this concentration because its topic fits this concentration:

         <write the full title of the Master Thesis>
         <write the full name and email address of the faculty who supervised your thesis>
         <for each semester during which you registered for ITCS 6991 write the semester and number of credit hours>

question: [COVID19] [Fall 2020] P/U Advice
answer:
Note:  This FAQ item only applies to the Fall 2020 situation and is for Computer Science Masters students only.


As CS Program Director, I present my advice below.  I first quote the Provost's announcement.   Then the first section contains my advice.  The second section contains additional linked references from various policies that lead to the advice.

From [https://provost.uncc.edu/pandemic/graduate-grading-policy-exception, accessed 12/7/2020]:

Due to disruptions during the Fall 2020 term resulting from the pandemic, the Graduate School is extending the deadline for students to request Pass/Unsatisfactory grading for their Fall 2020 courses until December 14, 2020.Some courses may be excluded from this option, such as core courses requiring a grade of B or better.

To request a Pass (P) grade to replace a C grade this semester, students must:
  • Submit an Academic Petition and select the request type “Other Course-Related.”
  • The request must be made prior to the grading period or by December 14, 2020.
  • Instructors and program directors must approve the student’s request. Graduate students are advised to consult with their program director before requesting a grade change selection, if relevant.
  • The P/U grade option is not available for Incomplete grades.

As always, students who earn a U or an unacceptable amount of C grades will be suspended or terminated, as appropriate.This process will not change for Fall 2020, and suspensions or terminations will be effective for Spring 2021. Graduate students are required to have a 3.0 GPA in their program of study in order to graduate.  Therefore, Pass (P) grading can be elected to replace only grades of A, B, or C.  Unlike undergraduates, graduate students are held to a higher standard and, as a result, are suspended when they earn a grade of U or an unacceptable number of C grades.

CS MS PROGRAM ADVICE

Primary Actions:

  • [A1] This Fall 2020:   For a Core Course, do not request a P/U if you have a B or better.

    Getting a P instead of B will cause that course to not count towards the Core Requirement.  As a result, the course (with a P) will only count as an Elective.

    Regulating Policy:  See S1  and S3 below.
  • [A2] This Fall 2020:   For a Concentration Course, do not request a P/U if you have a B or better.

    Getting a P instead of B will cause that course to not count towards the Core Requirement.  As a result, the course (with a P) will only count as an Elective.

    Regulating Policy:    See S1 and S4 below.
    Alternative Solutions:  See A4, A5, and perhaps A7.
  • [A3]  For an Elective Course, if you have a B or better think carefully before requesting a P/U.

    Overall, I do not recommend doing this, but the choice is up to each student. 
    It’s up to each student considering this action to calculate the effect of a P vs B on your overall GPA.   (Recall, a P grade is not used to compute your GPA [https://registrar.uncc.edu/gradingholds/grade-legend]).

  • [A6]  For any course, if you are are likely to get C, then consider carefully the following items and consider requesting a P.

    Again, neither a P (in Fall 2020) nor a C (at any time) is sufficient for a course to contribute to the Core or Concentration; it can only contribute as an Elective.  Further if you get more than 2 C's or a U you will get suspended (see S2).

    Therefore, a P is better than a C – regardless of which Program requirement (Core, Concentration, Elective, etc.) that you originally intended to apply the course to.

    Alternative Solutions:  See A7 (requesting an Incomplete).

Secondary Actions:

  • [A4]  Alternative Solution #1 to Situation A2

    If you are struggling with A2, consider the option of dropping your Concentration and declaring "No Concentration".

    Recall, the CS MS Program does not require a Concentration to graduate.   (You can change/remove a Concentration easily and change your mind multiple times; see  How do I declare a standard Concentration or choose "No Concentration"?).  

    Also recall:
    • A Concentration does not appear on your diploma.
    • A Concentration only appears on your transcript.
    Resume-wise, when creating a resume for a potential employer, it is reasonable to state that you “specialized” or “focused” in some area and list the courses you took in that area -- even if you did not formally have a Concentration.  

    Students who in normal (non-COVID) circumstances chose not to declare a Concentration often do this on their resume.   This approach is acceptable, because the term “specialize” and/or “focus” is not an official term in the CS MS Program.

    Having a Concentration on your transcript may feel more satisfying, but if you are choosing between delaying graduation and dropping your concentration, I suggest you are better off dropping the Concentration (unless you have other reasons to extend your CS MS studies).  Again, concentration changes are easy: How do I declare a standard Concentration or choose "No Concentration"?. 


  • [A5]  Alternative Solution #2 to Situation A2 or A3  

    Another option is as follows.  Take a P in the course that you had intended to contribute to the Core or Concentration requirement and accept that the course will no longer contribute to your Core or Concentration requirement. 

    Now, the P course can only count as an Elective.  

    At this point, your options for contributing to your Core or Concentration requirement are as follows:
    • [A5.1] For a Core or Concentration requirement, you could repeat the course (take it again) again in a later semester and get a B or better.    See "Repeating Graduate Courses" in the Catalog at this [link].    Note, with this action, [A5.1], your first iteration of the course (which earned the P) will obviously not count as  elective.

    • [A5.2] For a Core or Concentration requirement, you could take another course that is listed as counting toward the Core or Concentration requirement.

      Risks/Benefits:
      • Positives:   This might solve your problem
      • Negatives:  It might force you to take a total of more than 30 hours of courses in order to meet all graduation requirements.
      The evaluation of the above trade-off will completely depend on your individual circumstances.   Also, observe that with [A5.2] you must still make a B or better in the (possibly) extra course for it to count towards your Core or Concentration.
    • [A5.3] For a Concentration requirement, you could switch to another Concentration (assuming you do not choose to declare No Concentration).   Off all the options, this probably requires the most planning and is the most complex. 

      Risks/Benefits:
      • It maybe risky if the other Concentration requires courses that are not offered very frequently (see https://cci.uncc.edu/academics/computer-science/masters-program/ms-course-rotation and Course Rotation and "On Demand" Courses)
      • It may simply not be worth the added stress and effort compared to simpler actions, such as [A4]

  • [A7] Alternative Solution #3 to Situation A2, A3 or possibly A6.

    If you likely to get a C or U, a third option is to try to request and negotiate an Incomplete in a course.   An Incomplete has it's own special requirements and it is up to the instructor's discretion whether to grant an Incomplete.

    Due to the COVID pandemic, Student Assistance and Support Services (SASS) has added a page with special advice on requesting an Incomplete, see https://sass.uncc.edu/services/incomplete-grade-request.

MOTIVATING POLICIES:


[S1] University Policy (COVID Exception) :

From  [https://provost.uncc.edu/pandemic/graduate-grading-policy-exception, Accessed 12/7/2020]

"Due to disruptions during the Fall 2020 term resulting from the pandemic, the Graduate School is extending the deadline for students to request Pass/Unsatisfactory grading for their Fall 2020 courses until December 14, 2020.  Some courses may be excluded from this option, such as core courses requiring a grade of B or better.
To request a Pass (P) grade to replace a C grade this semester, students must:

  • Submit an Academic Petition and select the request type “Other Course-Related.” 
  • The request must be made prior to the grading period or by December 14, 2020. 
  • Instructors and program directors must approve the student’s request. Graduate students are advised to consult with their program director before requesting a grade change selection, if relevant.
  • The P/U grade option is not available for Incomplete grades. 

As always, students who earn a U or an unacceptable amount of C grades will be suspended or terminated, as appropriate.  This process will not change for Fall 2020, and suspensions or terminations will be effective for Spring 2021. 
Graduate students are required to have a 3.0 GPA in their program of study in order to graduate.  Therefore, Pass (P) grading can be elected to replace only grades of A, B, or C.  Unlike undergraduates, graduate students are held to a higher standard and, as a result, are suspended when they earn a grade of U or an unacceptable number of C grades." 

[S2] University Policy   A graduate student getting more than two C’s or a single U will be suspended from their graduate program.   For more details see What happens if I receive more than 2 C's or an U?  

[S3] CS MS Program Policy: As recorded in the Graduate Catalog, a course may only contribute to the CS MS Program Core Course requirement if the grade is a grade of “B or better”.    (DegreeWork reiterates this).    This means a P is not sufficient.

[S4] CS MS Program Policy : As recorded in the Graduate Catalog, a course may only contribute to the CS MS Program Concentration Area Requirement if the grade is a grade of “B or better”.    (DegreeWork reiterates this).    This means a P is not sufficient.

question: [COVID19] [Spring 2020] Should I replace a B with a P?
answer:
Note:  This FAQ item only applies to the COVID19 Spring 2020 situation and is for Computer Science Masters students only.

  

Based on Exception to UNC Charlotte Academic Policy and Procedure: Grading , replacing a B with a P will generally not harm your graduation process.  From the previous link:

  • “a grade of Pass (P) will equate to a standard letter grade of A, B, or C.”
  • “a grade of Pass (P) will be sufficient to meet the student’s program progression requirements, but will not impact the student’s GPA.”

For students that are close to graduation :

      For students who are fairly close to graduating, we advise not to replace a B with a P, unless getting a B puts a student in danger of not meeting graduation GPA requirement (see [ link ] regarding the 3.0 minimum).  Our observation is the latter situation is rare -- it really only applies either (a) if a student already has 1 or 2 C's or (b) if a student has strong reason to believe they might get a C in a later semester.

     Finally, note, according to Exception to UNC Charlotte Academic Policy and Procedure :

 "students will be able to petition to have a P grade revert to the original letter grade with associated changes to GPA"

So if you now replace a B with a P, then when you reach graduation time, you can then calculate what your final graduation GPA would be if you reverted the P to a B.   If reverting would lower your graduation GPA, obviously you would leave the P in place.   But if the final graduation GPA would not change, you could submit the mentioned petition and revert the P's to B's.  Possibly a potential employer would deem the B better than a P (assuming once again that you would have the same final graduation GPA in with either the B or P).   Most likely this petition will be done with the online petition system used for all other graduate petitions (https://academicpetition.uncc.edu/).

For students that are new in Spring 2020 :

      For a new student our advice is slightly more nuanced.   Some things to consider are as follows:

(1)  If you are concerned that in future semesters you might get a C (only 2 C's are allowed, (see [ link ]), then keeping your GPA as high as possible now is useful because graduation requires at least a 3.0 final GPA.

(2)  If you are confident that in future semesters you will only get A's and it is important to you personally to graduate with a very high GPA, then go ahead and replace B the with P.

(3)  If you are confident that in future semesters you will only get A's and B's, then there is little advantage to replace a B with a P.

Revert Spring 2020 P back to Original Letter Grade

     Finally, note, according to Exception to UNC Charlotte Academic Policy and Procedure :

 "students will be able to petition to have a P grade revert to the original letter grade with associated changes to GPA"

So if you now replace a B with a P, then when you reach graduation time, you can then calculate what your final graduation GPA would be if you reverted the P to a B.   If reverting would lower your graduation GPA, obviously you would leave the P in place.   But if the final graduation GPA would not change, you could submit the mentioned petition and revert the P's to B's.  Possibly a potential employer would deem the B better than a P (assuming once again that you would have the same final graduation GPA in with either the B or P).  

To do so, file a petition at https://academicpetition.uncc.edu/.    Select petition Type "Other - Course Related".   Then select the course with the P grade.  In the description describe that you are requesting to revert your to to the original letter grade.

question: [Early Entry Program]:  Problems registering for 5xxx Sections
answer:
Generally, you must register for the graduate section of any course in order for the course to count towards your CS MS Degree (see How does "double counting" work in the Early Entry Program?).    Below is a trouble shooting guide.

If you are having trouble registering for cross-listed course, follow the instructions below for the given situation.


Situation I:    The 5xxx course is full and the 4xxx section is full.

  1. In this case all you can do is join the wait list for the 5xxx course.

Situation II:    Both the 5xxx course and the 4xxx section have an open seat, but when you try to register for the 5xxx course you get a "level restriction" error.  

  1. Register for the 4xxx section immediately.
  2. Typically the "level restriction" indicates the Grad. School has not received your Early Entry Form for this particular course.
    1. If you have not submitted the EE Form, do so immediately , see How does "double counting" work in the Early Entry Program?
    2. If you did submitted the EE Form, contact the  Graduate Program Coordinator for additional help.
  3. After resolving the "level restriction" error in step #2 and if the 5xxx still has an open seat, then simultaneously drop the 4xxx section and add the 5xxx section.
    1. If the 5xxx is unfortunately now full, then you will have to follow the instructions in Situation III (below).

Situation III:   The 5xxx course is full and the 4xxx section has an open seat.

   Action III-A:

  1. Register for the 4xxx section.

  2. Email the professor who is teaching the cross-listed course and CC cgovan@uncc.edu and cs-ms-director@uncc.edu

    Explain that your are in the Early Entry program, why you are trying to register for the 5xxx section, and why you are unable to so.
    Sometimes, the professor and the CS department will be able to add another seat to 5xxx.     (Note, the CS department cannot do this for ITIS courses).

    Note, there are university policies that may prevent this, such as fire codes that limit capacity of rooms seating, etc.
  3. The Graduate Program Director will inquire whether your 4xxx seat can be converted into a 5xxx and will get back to you.
  4. If the Graduate Program Director (or other faculty member) replies that the seat can be converted, you will also receive specific further instructions in the email.

    Note:  Most of the time this solution will be possible.

  Action III-B:

  1. If the Graduate Program Director (or other faculty member) replies that the seat cannot be converted, then do the following:
    1. Stay registered in the 4xxx level course during the target semester.
    2. Inform the professor of your situation so that she can make sure you perform any extra course work required for the 5000 level students.
    3. During the semester, submit a petition (https://academicpetition.uncc.edu/)
      1. Select the type "Course Substitution"
      2. Select the 4xxx course you registered for.
      3. In the "Justification", copy, paste and modify the xxx text in following message:

        I am enrolled in the Early Entry program.   To double count course 4 xxx /5 xxx I need to enrolled the 5000 section. However, it is full and I can only enroll in the 4000 section. I have followed the instructions at the FAQ Early Entry Program: Problems registering for 5xxx Sections but was still unable to enroll in the 5000 section.   Therefore, I request a course substitution such that this 4000 course will count also as the 5000 toward my CS MS program.   

        I have informed the professor that I am doing this and I will perform any extra course work the professor requires for the 5000 level students.
      4. The Graduate Program Director will approve this petition after confirming with the professor that you performed any extra work required for 5000 level students.

        Note:  It may take up to week for the petition to move through the system.

question: How does "double counting" work in the Early Entry Program?
answer:
First Semester:  Hold - Early Entry Form

As soon as you receive admit letter and you declare your Intent-to-Enroll through the Graduate Application Portal, the University puts a "Early Entry Program" hold on your registration

To remove this hold, you must immediately do the following.

Fill out an Early Entry Program Petition at academicpetition.uncc.edu.

  1. When creating the petition, for Petition Level select "Graduate" and for Petition Type select "Early Entry".  This will display a petition form similar to the one below:
  2. Fill out the petition in consultation with your Undergraduate Adviser.
  3. On the form, list at least one grad. course that you want to take either (i) in your first Early Entry semester or (ii) in a future semester as an Early Entry student.

    While completing your BS you may double count up to 12 credits (4 hours) plus take one additional grad course which is not double counted.   For more details see Catalog: Computer Science, M.S., Early Entry.

    The listed grad. course can be taken either with double counting or without double counting.

    • To double count a course:  (1) you must list the both the grad. course and the double counted undergrad. course and  (2) for the Count Towards option you must select "Undergraduate & Graduate"
      • Standard Double Counted Courses:     The list of standard double counted course pairings are at links below:

        • ITCS courses:  Computer Science, M.S., Early Entry
        • ITIS  courses:  SIS, M.S. Early Entry
      • Non-Standard Double Counted Courses:
        • Consult with your Undergraduate Adviser on any desired non-standard, double counted course pair.

        • 3000/6000 ITCS Courses:   Since the 2018-2019 Catalogs, no ITCS 3000-6000 double-counting course pairings exist.
          Early Entry students must meet the requirements of the Catalog year under which they are graduating.
          Exceptions will only be granted in rare circumstances and the Early Entry Petition making the special request must be submitted prior to taking the ITCS course.

    • To not double count a course, for the Count Towards option select "Graduate Only".  

  4. Submit the Petition.
  5. The Petition will be automatically, electronically routed to a sequence of individuals for their approval.   The sequence is your Undergraduate Advisor, then your Graduate Advisor, then the CS MS Program Director and eventually the Registrar's Office.
  6. When the Petition is approved by Registrar's Office, you will receive an email indicating approval.
  7. At that point, you still must register for the graduate section of the course in order for double counting to occur.

Later Semesters

Typically you will submit additional Early Entry Program Petitions for later semesters.   

The Petition must be completed before the first day of classes of the semester in you wish to take the listed course(s).

The procedure to follow for these additional Petitions is the same as discussed above in Section "First Semester".

question: What rules govern grade point average (GPA) and repeating courses?
answer:
The following is excepted from the Graduate Catalog 2018 | 19, page 62:

"Repeating Graduate Courses

Graduate students are allowed to repeat a maximum of two courses in which the student has been assigned a grade of C or U (but not an I). If the course grade has resulted in suspension or termination of enrollment, the student must appeal to be reinstated in order to repeat the course. A given course may be repeated one time only. Each grade earned in a repeated course is shown on the student’s transcript. The record of the first attempt remains a part of the student's permanent record and counts in the number of marginal (C) grades accumulated. However, the hours earned and grade in the first attempt are not computed in the GPA. Successfully repeating a course does not change the number of marginal (C) grades accumulated. Enrollment will be terminated if a student receives a grade of U in a repeated course for which the student previously earned a U."

"Grade Point Average (GPA)

The grade point average for a graduate student is based only on those graduate courses taken at UNC Charlotte. It is determined by multiplying the number of grade points for each grade (A=5, B=3, C=2, U=0) by the number of credit hours credit received in that courses adding all accumulated grade points together, and then dividing by the total number of credit hours the student has attempted except those for which the student received a grade of I, IP, W, P, N, AU, or NR. When a course not listed as "May be repeated for credit" is repeated, no additional credit hours attempted accrue and the hours earned and grade points of the previous grade are replaced by those of the current grade. 

Graduate students must have a 3.0 GPA in the courses on their degree plan of study in order to graduate. However, the grades for all courses attempted will remain on the transcript and will be included in the calculation of the student’s GPA as it is reported on the transcript (except as described in the above paragraph)."

question: What happens if I receive more than 2 C's or an U?

If you receive more than 2 C's or 1 U grade (graduate courses), you will be suspended from the university and you will be un-registered from any classes you registered for in the subsequent semester. The university calendar gives the date that suspension letters are sent to students (a few days after the last day for grades to be posted). Note: Suspension/termination letters are done by the graduate school and the graduate coordinator is not involved in these letters being issued.

You may appeal the suspension as described in the Graduate Catalog | 2020/2021 in the "Academic Standing" chapter found at this link.

question: What is a grade of "I"?

"The grade of “I” is assigned at the discretion of the instructor when a student who is otherwise passing has not, due to circumstances beyond his/her control, completed all the work in the course. The missing work must be completed and the final grade reported within one calendar year from the date on which the “I” grade was recorded. The instructor assigning the “I” grade may specify a shorter time than one year for completion of the work and the assignment of a final grade. If the “I” is not removed during the specified time, a grade of “U” or “ N” as appropriate is automatically assigned."

Generally, students will not be able to extend an I grade beyond one semester and in any event there must be a valid reason for an I grade.

question: How do I register for ITCS 6490 Industrial Internship?
answer:
From the 2020/21 Graduate Catalog

ITCS 6490 - Industrial Internship

Full- or part-time academic year internship in computer science areas complementary to the concentration area of studies and designed to allow theoretical and course-based practical learning to be applied in a supervised industrial experience. Each student’s internship program must be approved by the supervising faculty, the academic advisor, and the graduate program director. A mid-term report and a final report to be evaluated by the supervising faculty are required. Grading is on a Pass/Unsatisfactory basis by the supervising faculty in consultation with off-campus supervisor at the internship organization. The credit hours may not be part of the minimum 30 credit hours for graduation.


(Source: Graduate Catalog | 2020/2021 : ITCS 6490, accessed 1/20/2021).

Details

You must do the following:

  1. Obtain an internship with a company. Must be closely related to Computer Science. (The Computer Science department does not offer a service for finding internships.)
  2. Find a faculty member who is willing to supervise internship (not the graduate coordinator).
  3. Fill in departmental ITCS 6490 industrial internship proposal form (here).
  4. Get supervisor's signature.
  5. Attach a letter from the company indicating that they will offer the internship and describing the work involved.
  6. Give form and letter to the CS MS Graduate Coordinator.    She will pass it onto the M.S. Program Director.
  7. If everything in order, form will be signed and you will be permitted to register.
  8. Although the section is in the name of the M.S. Program Director, the faculty supervisor listed on the proposal form supervises the work and assigns the final grade, which is entered by the M.S. Program Director.

ITCS 6490 can be helpful in certain of circumstances.   For example, some students are required to take a minimum number of credits per semester due scholarships, visa status, etc.

question: I want to complete my Qualifying Exam, what do I do?
answer:
Step 1.  Student → Make sure you are on track

  • You are strongly recommended to pass your qualifying exam within 2 years since entering the CIS Ph.D.

  1. Student → Get a clear idea of the expectation by reading the paragraphs about qualifying exam on the graduate catalog - LINK
  2. Student → Prepare a written research survey that describes the research area that you are expected to do his/her dissertation research in.

Step 3.  Student → 2 months before the qualifying exam, form the committee and set the date and time

  1. Student → Consult with your research advisor to create a committee.
    1. Select 3 faculty members to serve on your QE committee in addition to your advisor
    2. Note:
      1. The Qualifying Exam Committee should include at least three CIS Doctoral Faculty members, plus the student’s the Research Advisor.
      2. The Research Advisor is a non-voting member of the Qualifying Exam Committee.
  2. Student → Consult with your research advisor to set the date and time of the exam

Step 4.  Student → 1 months before the qualifying exam, send the information to the Director of Graduate Studies

  1. Student→ Complete the CIS Qualifying Exam Application.
    1. Note: If the core courses are satisfied through transfers, then put our own core course on that table.
  2. Student → Schedule the meeting via Zoom.uncc.edu. 

Step 5.  Student → 2 weeks before the qualifying exam, share the survey with the committee

  1. Student→ Provide copies of the written survey to the Committee members
    1. Tip → sharing a Dropbox link or Google Drive link helps you to keep updating and ensuring that the committee members always have the latest copy

    1. the Qualifying Exam rubrics from CCI. Please ensure that each committee member has this form - Qualifying Exam Rubrics.
    2. UNCC Graduate School Qualifying Exam Report.

    1. For each row, circle one of the columns

    1. qualifying exam report
    2. rubrics

    1. Go to the Tab of the semester

question: What's different about transfer credits from Advanced Standing?
answer:
With advanced standing,

  • You must have a master's degree in Computer Science, Software Information Systems, or Computer Engineering.
  • Advanced standing applies only to the Computer Science or Software Information Systems Track only.
  • You cannot transfer any credits
  • However, you only have 42 credits left to go on your degree.  Which is 30 credits less than the normal 72 credits
  • Other than declaring the advanced standing during the application process, no other actions are needed.
  • You must complete your qualifying exam after your first year in the program.

With transfer credits,

  • You can transfer up to 30 credits hours
  • You must file paperwork → see I want to transfer coursework from my MS into my PhD program, what do I do?
